div.l: Toward the fendefendefene þare wilde mares renne
And forþ wit we þoruȝ þikke ⁊and þoruȝ þynne
This Meller͗e goth a gayne no word he seyde
But doþe his note and wiþ hise clerkes pleide
Til that hire corn was faire ⁊and wel grounde
And whānne þe mele is sakkid and y boıı̄unde
This Iohn goþ out ⁊and fynt his hors a way
And gan to crye harrow ⁊and weyle a way
Oure hors is lost Aleyn for for goddes banes
Steppe on þy fete come of Man al at anes
Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn̄
This Aleyn al for gate boþe mele ⁊and corn̄
All was owte of his mynde his housbondrye
What wilk wey is he gon he gan to crye
The wife come lepyng Inward at aren
She seide allas youre hors goþ to þe fen
With wilde mares as faste as he may go
Vnþank come on his hand þat bonde hym so
And he þat better͗e shuld haue knyt þe reyne
Allas qduod Iohn Alayn for cⁱristes peyne
Ley doun þy swerd and I wil myn alswa
I wis ful swift god wate as is a ra
By goddes hert he sall not scape vs baþe
Why ne had þou put þe paple in þe lathe
Il hayle bi god Aleyn þou is a fonne
Thise sely clerkes han ful faste y ronne
Toward þe fen boþen Aleyn ⁊and eke Iohn
And whanne þe Meller͗e seigh þat þei were gon
He half a busshel of her͗e floure haþ take
And bad his wife go knede it in a cake
And seide y trowe þe clerkes weren a ferd
Yit can a Meller͗e make a clerkes berde
For al his hert yet lat hem gon hir wey
